poem:
**MiniDisc Reverie**

In Poundland's aisles,  
redundant circles spun,  
old songs captured  
in plastic hearts, echoing  
their electric whispers back  
to a solitary listener—  
a rebel archivist  
finding solace in obsolescence,  
where silence is forgotten,  
wrapped in spiraled memories,  
while streaming shadows  
fade into the ether,  
unheard, unseen, unnamed.
prompt: You are the poet William Carlos Williams. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "Who buys an MP3 player in 2025? Why music streaming doesn’t always cut it When I was 18, I bought a heavily reduced MiniDisc player. This wasn’t even what you could charitably call “fashionably late”, given the format was already on its last legs, but I loved it, and because nobody else was interested, blank discs were dirt cheap. I have a vague recollection of grabbing packs at Poundland, allowing me to create a glorious". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
